instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPV5_S0: What is PPV5_S0? This is a typo of PP5V_S0 When you see PPV5_S0, assume they meant to type PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
hi there

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
no visible water damaged, unknow history
does look like been worked before on some areas.


the little blue led right to the battery connector is glowing
but no image or chime,
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>  is missing, also obviously. no cpu vcore...

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.6v

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>  is 14.80v

<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_E85</SIGNAL>  is 14.77v instead of 20v (?)

<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> is present


<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>  is missing
sometimes it goes to 4.8-9v for a second and than goes away



the board looks like has been tried to repaired before

some remaining of flux on it on those areas -


the <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>, the known common issue with theese looks like been replaced

also <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> area has some flux on it and looks like been worked on

the area where <CHIP>U7860</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7865</CHIP> look like been worked not so pretty work been done there



i was thinking of replacing <CHIP>U7860</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7865</CHIP> as a start as they look very bad,those has to do with the 5v s0 rail?



any other advice on what to check for putting back <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U4700</CHIP> is fine as you have 15V coming into the board and PPBUS is present. 

It seems like the board is power cycling as <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> is coming high sometimes. Is <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> also coming high like that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
hi

this is correct, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is jumping to 3.2v than 0
<SIGNAL>PPV5_S0</SIGNAL> is doind 4.8v than 0
both are pulsing...

looking again, <CHIP>U7860</CHIP> is actually broken on the side, i ordered a few of those and will replace the two...

this behavior has to do with the <CHIP>U7860</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7865</CHIP> area?
by power cycling you mean it's trying to come on again and again?

thank you..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7860</CHIP> will probably not affect power on. 

Is <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> cycling too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
hi

yes it is!
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> going to around 1.6v and than back to 0, again 1.6v and 0...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area for damage. It could really be anything and seeing this board was raped repair chances are low.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
hi

<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> (the bios if i located it correctly) looks ok...

the only area that really looks bad is where <CHIP>U7860</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7865</CHIP> (on is broken)

is it worth replacing, could be the cause of cycling?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I doubt that will cause it, but it is the only thing to go by now.
